metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: AngularJS Form Validation
AngularJS can validate input data.
content.html: AngularJS can validate input data.

content.text: Form Validation
AngularJS offers client-side form validation.
content.html: AngularJS offers client-side form validation.

content.text: AngularJS monitors the state of the form and input fields (input, textarea, select), and lets you notify the user about the current state.
content.html: AngularJS monitors the state of the form and input fields (input, textarea, select), and lets you notify the user about the current state.

content.text: AngularJS also holds information about whether they have been touched, or modified, or not.
content.html: AngularJS also holds information about whether they have been touched, or modified, or not.

content.text: You can use standard HTML5 attributes to validate input, or you can make your own validation functions.
content.html: You can use standard HTML5 attributes to validate input, or you can make your own validation functions.

content.text: Client-side validation cannot alone secure user input. Server side validation is also necessary.
content.html: Client-side validation cannot alone secure user input. Server side validation is also necessary.

content.text: Required
Use the HTML5 attribute required to specify that the input field must be filled out:
content.html: Use the HTML5 attribute required to specify that the input field must be filled out:

content.code:
The input's valid state is:

{{myForm.myInput.$valid}}
content.code_html:
<form name="myForm">
  <input name="myInput" ng-model="myInput" required>
</form>

<p>The input's valid state is:</p>
<h1>{{myForm.myInput.$valid}}</h1>

content.text: E-mail
Use the HTML5 type email to specify that the value must be an e-mail:
content.html: Use the HTML5 type email to specify that the value must be an e-mail:

content.code:
The input's valid state is:

{{myForm.myInput.$valid}}
content.code_html:
<form name="myForm">
  <input name="myInput" ng-model="myInput" type="email">
</form>

<p>The input's valid state is:</p>
<h1>{{myForm.myInput.$valid}}</h1>

content.text: Form State and Input State
AngularJS is constantly updating the state of both the form and the input fields.
content.html: AngularJS is constantly updating the state of both the form and the input fields.

content.text: Input fields have the following states:
content.html: Input fields have the following states:

content.text: They are all properties of the input field, and are either true or false .
content.html: They are all properties of the input field, and are either true or false.

content.text: Forms have the following states:
content.html: Forms have the following states:

content.text: They are all properties of the form, and are either true or false .
content.html: They are all properties of the form, and are either true or false.

content.text: You can use these states to show meaningful messages to the user. Example, if a field is required, and the user leaves it blank, you should give the user a warning:
content.html: You can use these states to show meaningful messages to the user. Example, if a field is required, and the user leaves it blank, you should give the user a warning:

content.code: The name is required.
content.code_html:
<input name="myName" ng-model="myName" required>
<span ng-show="myForm.myName.$touched && myForm.myName.$invalid">The name is required.</span>

content.text: CSS Classes
AngularJS adds CSS classes to forms and input fields depending on their states.
content.html: AngularJS adds CSS classes to forms and input fields depending on their states.

content.text: The following classes are added to, or removed from, input fields:
content.html: The following classes are added to, or removed from, input fields:

content.text: The following classes are added to, or removed from, forms:
content.html: The following classes are added to, or removed from, forms:

content.text: The classes are removed if the value they represent is false .
content.html: The classes are removed if the value they represent is false.

content.text: Add styles for these classes to give your application a better and more intuitive user interface.
content.html: Add styles for these classes to give your application a better and more intuitive user interface.

content.code_html:
<style>
input.ng-invalid {
  background-color: pink;
}
input.ng-valid {
  background-color: lightgreen;
}
</style>

content.text: Forms can also be styled:
content.html: Forms can also be styled:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
form.ng-pristine {  background-color: lightblue;}
    form.ng-dirty {  background-color: pink;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
form.ng-pristine {  background-color: lightblue;}
    form.ng-dirty {  background-color: pink;}

content.code_html:
<style>
form.ng-pristine {
  background-color: lightblue;
}
form.ng-dirty {
  background-color: pink;
}
</style>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
form.ng-pristine {  background-color: lightblue;}
    form.ng-dirty {  background-color: pink;}

content.text: Custom Validation
To create your own validation function is a bit more tricky; You have to add a new directive to your application, and deal with the validation inside a function with certain specified arguments.
content.html: To create your own validation function is a bit more tricky; You have to add a new directive to your application, and deal with the validation inside a function with certain specified arguments.

content.code_html:
<form name="myForm">
<input name="myInput" ng-model="myInput" required my-directive>
</form>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.directive('myDirective', function() {
  return {
    require: 'ngModel',
    link: function(scope, element, attr, mCtrl) {
      function myValidation(value) {
        if (value.indexOf("e") > -1) {
          mCtrl.$setValidity('charE', true);
        } else {
          mCtrl.$setValidity('charE', false);
        }
        return value;
      }
      mCtrl.$parsers.push(myValidation);
    }
  };
});
</script>

content.text: Example Explained:
In HTML, the new directive will be referred to by using the attribute my-directive .
content.html: In HTML, the new directive will be referred to by using the attribute my-directive.

content.text: In the JavaScript we start by adding a new directive named myDirective .
content.html: In the JavaScript we start by adding a new directive named myDirective.

content.text: Remember, when naming a directive, you must use a camel case name, myDirective , but when invoking it, you must use - separated name, my-directive .
content.html: Remember, when naming a directive, you must use a camel case name, myDirective, but when invoking it, you must use - separated name, my-directive.

content.text: Then, return an object where you specify that we require ngModel , which is the ngModelController.
content.html: Then, return an object where you specify that we require  ngModel, which is the ngModelController.

content.text: Make a linking function which takes some arguments, where the fourth argument, mCtrl , is the ngModelController ,
content.html: Make a linking function which takes some arguments, where the fourth argument, mCtrl, is the ngModelController,

content.text: Then specify a function, in this case named myValidation , which takes one argument, this argument is the value of the input element.
content.html: Then specify a function, in this case named myValidation, which takes one argument, this argument is the value of the input element.

content.text: Test if the value contains the letter "e", and set the validity of the model controller to either true or false .
content.html: Test if the value contains the letter "e", and set the validity of the model controller to either true or false.

content.text: At last, mCtrl.$parsers.push(myValidation); will add the myValidation function to an array of other functions, which will be executed every time the input value changes.
content.html: At last, mCtrl.$parsers.push(myValidation); will add the myValidation function to an array of other functions, which will be executed every time the input value changes.

content.text: Validation Example

content.code:
Validation Example

Username:
      Username is required.  

Email:
      Email is required.   Invalid email address.
content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<h2>Validation Example</h2>

<form  ng-app="myApp"  ng-controller="validateCtrl"
name="myForm" novalidate>

<p>Username:<br>
  <input type="text" name="user" ng-model="user" required>
  <span style="color:red" ng-show="myForm.user.$dirty && myForm.user.$invalid">
  <span ng-show="myForm.user.$error.required">Username is required.</span>
  </span>
</p>

<p>Email:<br>
  <input type="email" name="email" ng-model="email" required>
  <span style="color:red" ng-show="myForm.email.$dirty && myForm.email.$invalid">
  <span ng-show="myForm.email.$error.required">Email is required.</span>
  <span ng-show="myForm.email.$error.email">Invalid email address.</span>
  </span>
</p>

<p>
  <input type="submit"
  ng-disabled="myForm.user.$dirty && myForm.user.$invalid ||
  myForm.email.$dirty && myForm.email.$invalid">
</p>

</form>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('validateCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.user = 'John Doe';
  $scope.email = 'john.doe@gmail.com';
});
</script>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The HTML form attribute novalidate is used to disable default browser validation.
content.html: The HTML form attribute novalidate is used to disable default browser validation.

content.text: Example Explained
The AngularJS directive ng-model binds the input elements to the model.
content.html: The AngularJS directive ng-model binds the input elements to the model.

content.text: The model object has two properties: user and email .
content.html: The model object has two properties: user and email.

content.text: Because of ng-show , the spans with color:red are displayed only when user or email is $dirty and $invalid .
content.html: Because of ng-show, the spans with color:red are displayed only when user or email is $dirty and $invalid.
